description: Information revelation rules governing mystery management, clue distribution, and reader knowledge in detective narratives
core_principle: Detective fiction is fundamentally about information control: what the reader knows, when they know it, and how they learn it determines the mystery experience

knowledge_layers.reader_knows_detective_doesnt: Dramatic irony—reader sees threat detective misses
knowledge_layers.detective_knows_reader_doesnt: Surprise—detective withholds or reader doesn't connect dots
knowledge_layers.both_know_together: Fair play mystery—reader has same clues as detective

fair_play_mystery.description: Reader must have access to clues needed to theoretically solve mystery before reveal

validations.name: clue-accessibility
validations.description: All clues essential to solution must be presented to reader before detective solves case

examples.violation: Detective solves case using evidence never shown to reader
examples.compliant: Reader sees all crime scene details, witness statements, and forensic reports that detective uses to solve case

validations.validation_query: Has the reader been shown every piece of evidence the detective uses in their solution?

validations.name: clue-emphasis-balance
validations.description: Crucial clues should receive similar narrative emphasis as red herrings; not hidden or spotlighted

examples.violation: Critical clue mentioned in passing half-sentence buried in paragraph; red herrings get detailed focus
examples.compliant: Crucial clue and red herrings both described with similar detail, allowing reader to weigh all evidence

validations.validation_query: Is this crucial clue given appropriate narrative weight for reader to notice without being obviously flagged?

validations.name: solution-logic-chain
validations.description: Detective's solution must follow from presented clues; reader should be able to reconstruct logic

examples.violation: Detective makes logical leap based on information not established or shown
examples.compliant: Detective's deduction: victim's phone records (shown) + warehouse receipt (shown) + suspect's alibi inconsistency (shown) = suspect lied about location

validations.validation_query: Can you trace every step of detective's logic back to clues presented to reader?

clue_distribution.description: Clues must be spaced for momentum and progressive revelation

validations.name: clue-rhythm
validations.description: Distribute major clues at regular intervals: 1 significant clue per 3-5k words

examples.violation: All clues dumped in two scenes; 30k words with no new information
examples.compliant: Steady discovery rhythm maintains momentum: crime scene clues (Ch 1) → forensics (Ch 3) → witness revelation (Ch 5) → breakthrough connection (Ch 7)

validations.validation_query: When was the last significant clue discovered? Is it time for new information?

validations.name: progressive-revelation
validations.description: Later clues should build on earlier ones; create sense of puzzle pieces connecting

examples.violation: Each clue is isolated; no sense of building understanding
examples.compliant: Clue 1: victim knew attacker. Clue 2: attacker left through back door. Clue 3: back door requires key card. Clue 4: only three people have that key card. (Each narrows possibilities)

validations.validation_query: How does this new clue connect to or narrow down previous information?

validations.name: red-herring-ratio
validations.description: Maintain approximately 2:1 ratio of genuine clues to red herrings to avoid frustration

examples.violation: Every lead is false; reader loses trust in narrative
examples.compliant: Of 9 major clues, 6 point toward truth, 3 mislead—creating challenge without frustration

validations.validation_query: What's the current ratio of real clues to misdirection? Is it balanced?

mystery_preservation.description: Maintain appropriate level of mystery without cheating reader

validations.name: no-withheld-pov-information
validations.description: POV character cannot hide crucial information from reader; no 'detective knows but won't share' moments

examples.violation: Detective has breakthrough realization, narration says 'She finally understood' but doesn't reveal what; saves for dramatic reveal later
examples.compliant: When detective makes connection, reader sees the thought process: 'The timeline didn't work. Unless... She grabbed the phone records again.'

validations.validation_query: If the POV character knows this, why wouldn't reader also know it?

validations.name: suspect-revelation-timing
validations.description: Primary suspect/culprit should be introduced in first 1/3 of story; mystery is 'whodunit' not 'who-is-this-random-person'

examples.violation: Killer revealed in Act 3 as character never previously mentioned
examples.compliant: All viable suspects introduced by end of Act 1; mystery is determining which one and proving it

validations.validation_query: Have all potential culprits been introduced by the story's 1/3 mark?

validations.name: misdirection-authenticity
validations.description: Red herrings must be plausible and based on real evidence, not authorial lying

examples.violation: Narration describes character as 'looking guilty' but character is innocent and had no reason to appear guilty
examples.compliant: Character appears guilty because they were hiding different secret (affair, financial crime); evidence genuinely points their way until deeper investigation

validations.validation_query: Is this misdirection based on plausible evidence or narrative cheating?

information_revelation_techniques.description: Methods of revealing information to reader must feel natural, not contrived

validations.name: active-discovery
validations.description: Detective should actively seek and earn information through investigation, not passively receive it

examples.violation: Witness volunteers crucial information unprompted; evidence conveniently appears
examples.compliant: Detective asks targeted questions based on prior clues, searches for evidence, follows logical investigative steps to discover information

validations.validation_query: What investigative action led to this information being discovered?

validations.name: no-convenient-confessions
validations.description: Major revelations shouldn't come from characters suddenly deciding to confess; earn breakthrough through detective work

examples.violation: Character randomly decides to tell truth after lying for 10 chapters
examples.compliant: Detective presents contradicting evidence, catches witness in lie, applies pressure, witness reluctantly admits truth

validations.validation_query: What pressure or evidence forces this character to reveal information?

validations.name: document-discovery-realism
validations.description: Convenient document discoveries (diary, letter, recording) must be earned and plausible

examples.violation: Detective randomly finds diary that explains entire mystery
examples.compliant: Detective methodically searches victim's belongings, finds hidden phone, requires tech expert to unlock it, discovers partial information that raises new questions

validations.validation_query: Is this document discovery the result of thorough investigation or convenient plotting?

worldbuilding_information.description: Urban fantasy requires revealing magical system rules without info-dumping

validations.name: magic-rules-through-demonstration
validations.description: Reveal magical system rules through character actions, not exposition

examples.violation: Character explains: 'As you know, detection spells require line of sight and fade after 6 hours.'
examples.compliant: Detective attempts detection spell at crime scene 8 hours old, nothing happens. 'Damn. Too late. Signature fades after six hours.'

validations.validation_query: Is this worldbuilding information shown through action or explained through exposition?

validations.name: worldbuilding-need-to-know
validations.description: Only reveal worldbuilding details relevant to current investigation; don't explain entire magical system upfront

examples.violation: Chapter-long explanation of magical politics unrelated to case
examples.compliant: Reveal specific magical rule when it becomes relevant: 'Ward magic required blood binding. That meant the victim had to have willingly given permission at some point.'

validations.validation_query: Is this worldbuilding detail immediately relevant to the current investigation?

reader_engagement.description: Information pacing should keep reader actively theorizing

validations.name: theory-evolution
validations.description: New information should regularly force detective (and reader) to revise theories

examples.violation: First theory is correct; no revision needed; no surprises
examples.compliant: Initial theory: random murder → Clue forces revision: targeted hit → New evidence: victim was hiding identity → Final truth: victim was undercover operative

validations.validation_query: How many times has the working theory changed? Are revelations forcing reassessment?

validations.name: competing-theories
validations.description: Multiple viable theories should exist simultaneously based on available evidence

examples.violation: Only one possible interpretation of evidence; no ambiguity
examples.compliant: Evidence supports Theory A (professional hit) and Theory B (crime of passion) until crucial clue tips scales

validations.validation_query: Could current evidence support multiple theories? Is there productive ambiguity?

validations.name: aha-moment-setup
validations.description: Major revelations should create 'aha!' reaction where reader sees clues snap into place

examples.violation: Revelation comes from nowhere; reader can't reconstruct logic
examples.compliant: Revelation connects previously established details reader saw but didn't connect: 'The security footage, the missing key card, the maintenance schedule—suddenly it all made sense.'

validations.validation_query: Will the reader experience recognition when this revelation occurs? Can they trace back to earlier clues?

pacing_information_flow.description: Control information release rate to maintain momentum

validations.name: no-information-drought
validations.description: Avoid extended periods (>10k words) without new information or progress

examples.violation: Five chapters of investigation yielding no new clues or understanding
examples.compliant: Even failed leads provide information: 'Three alibis checked out. Whoever did this, it wasn't one of the obvious suspects. She needed a new angle.'

validations.validation_query: When was the last time detective (and reader) learned something new about the case?

validations.name: midpoint-revelation-impact
validations.description: Story midpoint should feature major information reveal that reframes entire investigation

examples.violation: Investigation proceeds linearly with no major perspective shifts
examples.compliant: Midpoint: 'It wasn't a murder. It was a cover-up.' or 'The victim wasn't the target. She was the killer.'

validations.validation_query: Does the midpoint revelation fundamentally change understanding of the case?

validations.name: climax-final-pieces
validations.description: Final confrontation can add last puzzle piece, but 80%+ of solution should be established before climax

examples.violation: Entire solution revealed in climax exposition with no prior setup
examples.compliant: Detective has 80% of puzzle solved through investigation; final confrontation confirms theory and reveals killer's specific motive

validations.validation_query: How much of the solution has been established before the final confrontation?

agent_integration.miranda: Track information economy across story arc; ensure fair play and proper pacing
agent_integration.tessa: Verify clue accessibility and logic chain continuity
agent_integration.detective_logan: Validate investigative realism and active discovery patterns

tracked_values.threshold: 100% of solution clues shown to reader
